grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to indicate that the preceding event and the following one happened sequentially.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 지수는 친구에게 화분을 하나 얻어서 키우기 시작했다.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Jisoo got a flowerpot from her friend and started growing it.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A connective ending used for a reason or cause.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 지수는 시간이 없어서 식사도 못 했다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Jisoo couldn't even eat because she didn't have time.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to emphasize that the preceding statement is the cause, reason, or premise for the following statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 학교에 가야 되니까 지금 못 만나요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I need to go to school, so I won’t be able to meet
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 옆방이 아주 시끄러우니까 저는 잠을 못 잤어요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The room next to us is very loud, so I couldn’t sleep

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used to express the purpose of an action such as going and coming.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Suddenly, my friends came to my house to hang out.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 어머니는 과일을 사러 잠깐 시장에 가셨다
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: My mother went to the market to buy some fruit

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that one has the intention or wish to do the act mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I try to get up early from tomorrow.
grammar.gramInDepth2: An expression used to indicate that the incident mentioned in the preceding statement is likely to happen or begin soon.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 비가 오려고 하는지 구름이 잔뜩 끼었다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: It was cloudy as if it was about to rain.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A connective ending used when more than two actions or states happen at the same time.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I drank cola while watching a movie

grammar.gramInDepth1: To indicate that one action occurs “when or if” another action (that hasn’t happened yet) occurs
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 집에 일찍 도착하면 빨래를 할 거예요
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: If I arrive home early, I will do laundry
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 내일 비바람이 오면 경기가 취소될 거예요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: If it storms tomorrow, the match(game) will be cancelled

grammar.gramInDepth1: A sentence-final ending used when the speaker confirms and says something that the listener thought he or she already knew.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: The movie I watched today was a bit boring.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A sentence-final ending used to ask something that the speaker already knows to cross-check the information.

grammar.gramInDepth1: A sentence-final ending used to indicate a question or assumption about something.
grammar.gramInDepth2: A sentence-final ending used to ask for the listener's opinion.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Shall we go to dinner together?

grammar.gramInDepth1: A sentence-final ending used to indicate the speaker's intention to do something in the future, or to ask for the listener's thoughts about that.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I'm tired today, so I'm going to bed early.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 내일 산에 갈 때 몇 시에 출발할래요?
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: What time do you want to leave when you go to the mountain tomorrow?

grammar.gramInDepth1: (formal) A sentence-final ending used to express an intention of doing a certain action together.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: It's late, so let's go quickly.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Let’s enforce that rule starting tomorrow

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used when the speaker promises or notifies the listener that he orshe will do something.
An expression used to indicate that a certain act is allowed or accepted.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 박물관 안에서 사진을 찍어도 될지 물어 보자.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: Let's ask if we can take a picture inside the museum.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: May I go to the bathroom?

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to decide or promise the performance of the act mentioned in the preceding statement.
grammar.inDepth1ExEng: I decided to meet my friend in the park
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 내일 친구랑 음악회에 같이 가기로 했어요
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: I decided to go to the concert with my friend tomorrow

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the act or state mentioned in the preceding statement existed at some point in time.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: Have you ever been to Japan?

grammar.gramInDepth1: An expression used to indicate that the act or state mentioned in the preceding statement never existed.
grammar.inDepth1ExKor: 나는 스페인에 가 본 적이 없다.
grammar.inDepth2ExKor: 나는 그런 생각을 해 본 적이 없다.
grammar.inDepth2ExEng: The thought never entered my head.
